reviewText:
Stealth, gadgets and options.

Game mechanics:
The perfect stealth gameplay. I was impressed with this game, most of the time you'll have games where you have the choice to go stealth or go crazy; But rarely are both options actually rewarded equally. Stealth usually tends to be the more benificial one, but not here. Blacklist is designed to reward three diffferent playstyles, assualt, stealth and assassin

Each playstyle actually has their own point system and side missions that focus on each skill. It is an extremely well rounded game.

Gameplay:

So many cool gadgets, gadgets that can actually be gamechanging in ways that are not toi overpowering. Scout out an area with a drone, use a sticky camera to monitor an area or distract gaurds as you sneak past, its just so well designed and fun. Really it was a game that I didn't want to end.

10/10 Best PC stealth game I've played.

reviewText:
Just bought the game, and played not longer than 1 hour. Below are the true reviews!

Pro:
1. Good graphics
2. The weapons, armor upgrades etc are something to look forward to and interesting.
3. Gameplay so far (30 mins) are good!

Con:
1. Can only play for 23 mins before the game crashes. Game will crash precisely on 23 mins for me. Searched the forum, some will crashed at 25 mins, some 50 mins. But the timing is precise, only different timing for different users. And no, my PC spec is way higher to support this game.
2. User cannot save the game manually, all depends on auto-save. Meaning if you get caught in a stealth mission, most of the time you need to go ALL the way back to the front and re-play everything again! And since there's no manual saves, I need to complete every mission within 23 mins (before it crashes), if not, I'll have to re-play the mission from the beginning.
3. Cannot go online. Meaning cannot redeem those ULC that I've paid.
4. Since cannot go online, meaning cannot join multiplayer game.

Still waiting for Ubisoft to fix my problem. Until they're fixed, especially for crashes, I'll not recommend this game for everyone.

Update on 10 March 2014:
The only fix for the above mentioned problem is to reformat the HDD, and re-install a clean windows. Everything works fine after that.

Now onto the real gameplay, co-op mission is definitely fun. And I'm actually enjoy myself. Kudos for a good game from Ubisoft. Only drawback is.. well.. re-install windows is kinda tedious just to play the game don't you think?

reviewText:
Brilliant game, has moved back towards a stealth classic and away from the previous incarnations of action games.

There is a tonne of content with a large list of unlocks and an impressive number of missions. The multiplayer game modes are very good but the coop maps are excellent as well.

Level design allows for multiple paths in nearly all instances, combined with the different play styles allowed it offers replayability should you choose.

I recommend this to anyone who enjoys a well done stealth game with a sprinkling of shooting action.

The only real negative is Ubisoft's need to make you login through Uplay, this irks me slightly but does not detract from the game.

reviewText:
It's no Chaos Theory. But it's much closer to the series' roots than Conviction ever was. Darkness is back (shooting out lights protects your stealth), you have the capability to finish most missions without ever firing a shot (or even engaging anyone besides mission targets), and the weapons 4th Echelon gives you are all suppressed. You CAN pick up unsuppressed weapons, but if you want to preserve the true SC experience, don't do it!

There are linear sequences that feel way too much like Assassin's Creed, and the FPS sequences where you play as Briggs are definitely the low point. Difficulty is on the easy side (too much like AC again), with death from above" kills and 100% predictable AI (they always spawn in the same spots).

I did like the "Mass Effect" style inter-mission parts where you roam the plane
recommended: and upgrade your gear.\n\nCo-op missions (most of which can be played solo
hoursPlayed: but you can't access certain routes that way) are like Modern Warfare's coop or Halo's spartan assault
voteText: except with stealth and alarms. They are pretty fun and lack none of the lame parts seen in the solo campaign.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: I recommend picking this game up on sale. The E3 video previews made this look like a lame action game
votesHelpful: but you're given the option (and encouraged to) play super stealthily. Can't say I wouldn't prefer a more Chaos Theory kind of game though!"

reviewText:
Blacklist actually managed to make a game for stealthy fans AND / OR action fans alike.  Initially I questioned the option to play a Splinter Cell game with a run-n-gun style, but it does offer a degree of replay value.  Personally if you're playing it this way it seems to go against the logic of the super secret 4th Echelon group.  Regardless, when played correctly" Blacklist is an excellent addition to the Splinter Cell franchise.

The multiplayer is rather enjoyable when you find a game without a speed hacking aimbot using troll.  Spies v/s Mercs is awesome.

Buy it.  Play it.  Or else the terrorists win."

reviewText:
Splinter Cell Blacklist is a pretty good game, with lots of variation and ways to play the game to your advantage.

During my first play-through, I went with a 100% pacifist build, killing no-one throughout the entire campaign whenever I could avoid it. I used tools such as sleeping gas and drones to knock out and shock my enemies, respectively. The campaign - unlike other games which claim to allow you to play it your way" - truly gives challenges depending on what you want to do.

Sure
date: you could choose to do this unbelievably heavy non-stealth build where you shoot any guard who comes remotely close to you in the map
recommended: but on the missions where you're not allowed to kill guards you're going to have to adapt accordingly. You could choose to be a pacifist like me
hoursPlayed: but on the missions where the guards know exactly where you are
voteText: you're going to regret not having spent some points to have decent armour instead of your sticky shocker.\n\nThe game offers much more replayability compared to it's predacessor Splinter Cell Conviction

reviewText: For all my complaints on the new directon Splinter Cell has going over the last couple games this one feels like a good comprimise between the old and new.  At least this one gives you the option of stealth.  Well for the most part.  Brigg's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sections where they literally turn the game into a first person shooter is just horrible but thats like 2 parts and its really easy to get through them.  This for the most part makes a good comprimise.  Stealth is still a very viable option in the majority of missions.  In fact its very fun trying to get ghost rating on most missions.  Going action isn't such a bad thing either.  Different game mods offer a lot of variety.  Pure stealth missions that can be played alone or coop.  Previously mentioned kill every enemy in an area where stealth is encouraged similar to the one I talked about in Conviction, small maps with waves of enemies to kill are actually really fun to.  There's a whole side story thats all coop missions and I love them.\n\nThis is the game that got me into the multiplayer too!  The spies vs mercs gamemode is awesome!  Trying to be stealthy against other players is a true challenge.  I just wish playing as mercs wasn't a first person shooter but I guess gotta give the spies some advantage.  Top it all off with a story that doesn't feel like a stupid excuse to kill people.  The main villian feels fresh in a series where you can barely remember who it is.  I've compared Conviction to 24 but this one feels like the closest thing to a good 24 game I'll get.

reviewText:
This review will be detailed, if you would like to see my general thoughts, scroll to the bottom.

This review will cover the following:
- Singleplayer
- Multiplayer
- Bugs
- Customization


So, to kick this off, I'll give you a flashback, back in 2013. Being a huge fan of Splinter Cell Conviction, I couldn't wait to get my hands on it. Didn't preorder, because I was cautious, but nonetheless excited. Note this however, I first experieced my first hours of this on console, and bought the Deluxe Edition recently on sale for $10. The Xbox version was fine, no bugs that were game-halting. It was fun. So here we are now for the PC version.

Singleplayer: This is probably my favorite part of this game. The campaign missions have a good amount of replayability, whith the whole Ghost, Panther, and Assault deal. The campaign is fairly long and the story is interesting. They got a new voice actor for Sam Fisher, which disheartened me, but is not a major setback because the new one does well with keeping the same brisk, badass, get-to-the-point-or-I-will-kill-you tone we have all come to know and love. Overall, the singleplayer is fantastic.

Multiplayer: Alright, any bugs that are in the multiplayer will be explained in the bugs section. The multiplayer for Splinter Cell: Blacklist is quite fun. The Spies VS. Mercs mode returns and it's better than ever. You can't help but feel a pang of fear when you hear the slice of a blade into your buddy behind you and you turn around to see nothing but your friend's dead body, or the satisfaction of sucessfully performing such an attack on the mercs. The mercs are locked in first person, and can't see into the dark as well, but make up for it in sheer muscle and lead. Spies are locked in third person, and can see very well between light settings. Spies can climb onto or into almost anything, and while mercs can do a little themselves, they mostly just hop over shest high walls or drop to the floor below. Coop is also quite satisfying. It's hard to get a feeling quite equal to you and your bud tearing down a fortress all in silence.. or in glorious charges into the breach. That's possible too. Overall, the gameplay is fun and diverse.

Bugs: Okay, here's the party pooper. This game, like most Ubisoft games, have crippling connectivity issues. The singleplayer has little to no problems in terms of bugging out, but the multiplayer is a breeding ground for them. First things first, some people can't connect to the servers. Period. Even after this entire time of being out, Poobisoft can't get the issue fixed, or probably even consider it. Secondly, It's damn near impossible to connect to friends. There was a thread on Steam where someone posted a fix they had, but it was long and complicated. Some people were able to use third party programs where they were able to connect, like Hamachi. This same bug applies to coop, so a fat lot of good that does for you. Some people have even reported issues where they have had UPlay register them running two instances of the game and will refuse to launch. Game crippling bugs like this have been unattended to, and some people have even tried to petition for their money back. Also, at least for my friend and I, ALT+TAB puts you into windowed mode every time you do it. I have also had several times where the game will say Not Responding"
recommended: then pop up again. This is usually during launch.\n\nCustomization: This is a bright spot for Splinter Cell: Blacklist. The customization features many new weapons
hoursPlayed: all having many smaller customizations that can be added to them
voteText: like match point triggers
helpfulPercent: or hollow point ammunition. I was very pleased with the customization.\n\nHello to those who want a simple
votesHelpful: to-the-point review of Splinter Cell: Blacklist and hello to those who actually read the novel above. Well
votesTotal: down to the point. Splinter Cell: Blacklist is overall a decent game. The singleplayer is a good length with an interesting story
votesFunny: the multiplayer is incredibly buggy
commentsCount: and likely will never be fixed by Poobisoft
column16: so don't expect easy playing and connection to your friends. Bugs are rampant in the multiplayer
column17: but are mainly involving connectivity. Surprised? I'm not. The customization is very refreshing from earlier titles
column18: and is very well done. My score for Splinter Cell: Blacklist is a 6/10. It's fun
column19: but the bugs are game halting and ruin its experience for me. BUY IT ON SALE. It's not worth the full price."

reviewText:
No idea why it's taken me so long to review this game. This was easily my favorite game of 2013. I'm currently playing MGS V, and I feel so incredibly limited by Snake's moveset that I had to come back and play Splinter Cell. I get it...two completely different experiences...yadda yadda yadda. When I want an awesome stealth actioner, I'll take Blacklist over anything. I've beaten this game on Perfectionist so many times. It's awesome every time. Taking different approaches in each level. Every takedown feels righteous. Everything has impact. Karambit stealth kills are spectacular every single time. They never, ever get old.

Among my favorite stealth games of all time. While the story isn't all...whatever...at least it's not a convoluted mess as in the case of whatever passes for a story in the MGS world these days.

Get this game. It's cheap...but I'd still recommend purchasing it at full price.

reviewText:
I am giving this game a thumbs up not because it is a good game, which I've yet to determine, but because of the hidden DLC that comes with it.  Oh, I'm not talking about UPlay, no no, I'm talking about the hidden 'Gypsy Curse' DLC it comes packaged with.  This special DLC really brought the excitement to life.

Think I'm making things up?  Ha, I wish.

After running the gauntlet that was UPlay to get it installed and play it, I thought my trials were done, that I'd survived the worst the game had to offer.  What more could it do? I sat back and enjoyed being a badass black ops ♥♥♥-kicker.  Life was good.

Then my computer started making a weird noise.  Well, these things happen, everything seemed to be working fine.  I loaded into a mission, a pretty tough mission, and I put in the work to succeed.  Just as I'm about to exfiltrate and claim my reward, the Curse strikes.  My computer powers off suddenly.  What?  What could have happened?  Just a power surge, just gotta turn it back on and pick up where I left off.

No, wait, the power supply completely blew.  Burnt right out.  Dead.  Kaput.  Executed, if you will.  For the first time in my computer owning life, a part of my computer actually kicked the bucket.

Now I have to go out in the middle of the Chinese New Year and try to find a PSU.  Yeah, right.  Well, somehow I manage it, so the next day I'm out a hundred bucks and a day of holiday, but I can get back to playing. Alright!

I load back into that mission, and ghost it like a boss.  I turn to head for exfiltration, and the game closes suddenly.  Is it the power supply again?  No, it's the Curse.  This time in the form of a forced Windows update.  No warning, no option to delay, just bam, restart.

What could have been so important?  A security update for a version of Word I don't even use.

Do I dare boot the game a third time?  Do I risk suffering the curse?  Can I afford to?  What might happen next?

...literally as I was writing that last sentence my virus checker asked if it could restart the computer.

Play the game if you must, dear reader, but beware always...the Gypsy Curse! Also UPlay, which really sucks and added several hours to the set up of the game.

reviewText:
It's a very good game actually, the game system is improved since Conviction and very good adapted to the scenarios.
GOOD POINTS:
-IMPROVED GAMEPLAY SYSTEM
-ACCEPTABLE STORY MODE: Decisions that affects the story timeline and different paths to choose, so it's not so linear.
-NICE ONLINE MODE: Pretty nice game-modes,
-GOOD CUSTUMOMIZATION (WEAPONS, SUITS, GADGETS, VISION GOOGLES)
The game is not crashing at any moment and the frame rate is acceptable it's pretty stable

BAD POINTS
-BUGS DETECTED: Few visual bugs, but they're very notable on some scenarios, also there is one co-oop mission which you cannot quit if you don't finish the game by force.
-ONLINE GAME: Very bad matchmaking and sometimes the teams are unbalanced

CONCLUSION; It's worth it for the price that I paid, (100 MXN) and I bought the Deluxe Edition, so I think that if you buy it with disccount it won't dissapoint you

reviewText:
After the utter disapointment that were PC Double Agent and Conviction, needless to say I approached blacklist with a great dose of apprehension. In Splinter Cell terms, that means crouched and in the darkness. Be advised though, if you see pets crouched and in the darkness, usually it's a sign they are about to deliver a smelly present in your living space. But that's not the point.

So, it was a good thing that I was actually pleasantly surprised by Blacklist. Blacklist have a more open approach to missions which is akin to what Phantom Pain did, namely giving you a hub/nexus from where you decide which mission to tackle next, and which you can upgrade as well as upgrade and purchase gear using money you gain by completing said missions.

I kinda like that, and it helped the game controls were refined and actually more instinctive than in previous games. They aren't perfect, and prompts are still wonky, but it's getting there. Instead of forcing us into a more actionny gameplay that was in Conviction, Blacklist come back to the fundamentals of stealth, albeit with a more simple system than in Chaos Theory. It also leave room for people who want to play a more action type of gameplay, though it's not avaible for all missions, some having stealth requirements for scenario reason, and for people who don't want to go non lethal and avoid ennemies, but want to sneak around and cut throats and shoot people in the head. Each mission has you rated in thoses 3 categories(Ghost, Panther and Assault), and add replayability if you want to get the best score possible for each.

Side missions are gimmick missions with special conditions, which offers challenges and story in equal measure, and can, best all, be played in coop, which is a pretty good thing. Coop is actually pretty fun and usually enjoyable, albeit it suffers from a chatting system not working for a lot of people. The problem is, your partners aren't always playing with a style similar to your, so trying to get ghost mastery when you have a guy near you who is going loud and lobbing incendiary grenades everywhere can be quite a nuisance.

The single player campaign is mostly well done and enjoyable(though it has a few missions that are pretty annoying and meaningless and which could have been served better with a very long cutscene instead). Characters are surprisingly pretty well done, and we get to see how Sam has changed due to the events he had to go through. It hits a more grey moral zone. The story still has big chunks of Tom Clancy in it, and you will find again the cliché of having antagonists who are pretty much against the US dominion and must try very hard to not say capitalist pigs" every 5 seconds. The problem I have with that is it doesn't convey the real problems some of the third world countries

reviewText:
Without a doubt, 'Blacklist' is the best looking 'Splinter Cell' game to date. As a fan of the series' stealth gameplay in the first three games, I am quite pleased with its return in 'Blacklist'. The game plays like 'Chaos Theory', but with a dash of the quick action featured in 'Convction'. Still, as much as I like the Mark & Execute feature, I rarely used it in my playing. The game is best enjoyed if you play it in Ghost (stealth + non-lethal) or Panther (stealth + lethal) style.

The story in 'Blacklist' is your standard 'Splinter Cell' fare. It's formulaic, but enough to move the action along, and it seems to be the beginning of a bigger story arc. What really captured my attention in the game were Grim and Korbin's side missions -- because they remind me of what I love most about 'Chaos Theory' -- and the Gone Dark Intel Metagame. The latter plays like a modern version of 'Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego?' and it's a welcomed distraction.

The monetary system, in which you HAVE to earn money to upgrade weapons and gadgets, is superfluous. (Is the U.S. government in the game so cash-strapped that I have to buy my equipment in small increments?!) Sad to say, Eric Johnson, who took over for Michael Ironside for the role of Sam Fisher, failed to impress me. His voice acting was uneven and lacked the gravitas that Ironside's had. Johnson sounded like he was just imitating Ironside in one moment, and like a young man in the next. Johnson's voice work was disappointing.

Overall, 'Blacklist' is a worthy follow-up to 'Chaos Theory', a welcomed return-to-form after polarizing thematic departures in 'Double Agent' and 'Conviction'. and frankly what feels like a soft reboot to the franchise. Despite one or two (maybe three) glaring flaws that are hard to ignore, there are enough good points to 'Blacklist' that make it worth your time.

reviewText:
I loved the first three Splinter Cell games. The first Splinter Cell was billed as a Metal Gear Solid killer. As stealth games, both Metal Gear Solid and Splinter Cell both rewarded patient players, although Splinter Cell had a storyline far more grounded in reality.

The fourth Splinter Cell, Double Agent, went for something a little different. The fifth game, Conviction, went for something completely different, and Blacklist followed. I think that Conviction and Blacklist have turned the Splinter Cell games into a far more trigger happy series, and pumped in the action move cliches. Not that there's anything particularly wrong with that, the Syphon Filter games on the PSX paid lip-service to stealth while throwing action movie cliches at you all the time. And I loved those games.

So while I prefer the original games, I enjoyed my quick run through Blacklist, but I'm done with the main story, and probably won't play through any of the side stuff. The only major flaw is that Michael Ironside no longer voices Sam Fisher.

Blacklist is good, but not full price good, so wait for a crazy special or price drop.

reviewText: Another great game from Splinter Cell series. Playing as already well known agent of spy organization 4th Echelon, Sam Fisher - you are together with another spy, Briggs or with your friends completing missions to stop attacks of terroist organization called Blacklist. Really well created story, although Sam does not have the personality he used to have in previous Splinter Cell games. Easy to learn controls, high variety of gear, gadgets and other stuff. Lot of collectibles such as Dead Drops, High Value Targets ( also known as HVTs ), etc. You can purchase two DLCs, well fitting the game. I would buy them on sale personally, but they are cheap anways ( containing bonus weapons and aesthetic customizations + 2 extra maps ). Interesting multiplayer ( Spies vs Mercs - Mercenaries, also known as simply SvM ) with nice concept and high replayability. The game has cooperative mode, but is missing offline lan multiplayer from previous games. If you like stealth, this - is the choice for you. Also, rest in piece, Tom Clancy.

reviewText:
Let me get this out of the way: this is still a very ENJOYABLE game.

BUT!

Ubisoft's dumb decision #1: Why force everybody to watch the long intro movie and play the tutorial BEFORE giving them a chance to set graphics options? The game locks the resolution at 1945 x 926, and you can't even change it until after the first part.

Ubisoft's dumb decision #2: Replacing Michael Ironside as the voice actor for the protagonist. Now the voice just sounds like the generic steroid-pumped jarhead army grunt.

And that's why I only paid $9 for this game, instead of higher as I usually would for a Splinter Cell title.

Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Very entertaining stealth-based game that expands quite a bit on the previous game in the series, Splinter Cell Conviction.
If you have not played Conviction, then this review may or may not help you out too much.

AI, Movement, Weapons, Customization, Graphics, Optimization...It's all been vastly improved and edited. The AI notices when a teammate goes missing more often and they also remember when doors were suppose to be opened or closed. Movement has improved mostly for the realism side of things, you can't just crouch up to enemies anymore or else they'll be easily alerted.  Quite a few weapons have been added from Conviction and there are plenty of new guns aswell. Not to mention each gun has about 20 different attachments. With that I move onto customization which to be honest reminds me of ATV Offroad Fury or MX vs ATV Customization mostly because you can choose each piece of your stealth suit you wanna wear which can either increase or decrease Armor or Stealth. Graphics quality is on the level of Battlefield 3 in my opinion, mostly because of the Shadows and the High-Res Textures that Conviction lacked. Lastly, this game is FAR more optimized than conviction. Playing maxed out with No AA @ 1440x900 gives me anywhere from 50-80 FPS. Conviction never got higher than 55 FPS when I played it last.

A few things I forgot to mention is that you can now either take out enemies lethally or non-lethally. You can also move bodies to different locations. Enemies now have new toys such as Tank Drones, which will drive up and self destruct on you if you get spotted by one. They also have Heavy Suits and basically it makes your enemies about as tough as a juggernaut in other games.

Alright, I've listed all the pros I can think of. Now it's time to list the cons.
Okay, here I go...*Inhales Deeply*
......
Uplay...It's garbage. Why does this even exist? Sorry, I can't list anything else bad about this game.

So...is it worth it to drop 60 bucks on this game? Which by the way has an 8 hour (approx.) campaign, coop, and a 4vs4 multiplayer gamemode that is absolutely the most unique gamemode I have seen in a very long time. Well, that's for you to decide, and hopefully I've eased your decision making process a bit.

reviewText:
This iteration of the Splinter Cell series really puts my feelings for Ubisoft to the test. As far as single-player goes this is by far the best stealth-game I've played. Multiplayer (especially co-op missions) has the potential to make it one of the all-time greats, but that's where Ubisoft just didn't pull through for whatever reason. It's full of bugs that make prolonged game-sessions prone to all kinds of glitches that rarely turn out in your favor, mostly they screw you and potential hour-long efforts over for good.

Of course as it is with most Ubisoft games it is pretty much abandoned now update-wise so as much as I hate Ubisoft for their ways of doing business I have to admit that the game and its mechanics are pretty much as good as it gets as long as the god of multiplayer-bugs has mercy on you.

Bottom line: This game is too much fun for me not to play it but I would prefer it if Ubisoft at least delivered a finished product, be it on launch-day or through updates at a later time.

reviewText: To start off let me say this......This...is a DAMN good game. Now let me elaborate on that statement. Splinter Cell: Blacklist has taken Splinter Cell back to much needed stealth, back to its roots you could say. However, even by doing this they make it a new, refreshing feel to it, not just some reskin of Chaos Theory. With the games new 3 way level design 1.(kill all, be loud) 2.(Kill all, remain silent) and 3.(knock out, remain silent) 3 being my personal favorite. With this new system each and every level has so many different and unique design and ways of turning out, which makes for amazing adventure. This game is good, but it has its flaws here and there.\nA few things in this game don`t really add up when you start to think of them. Blacklist has a lot of things going for it except one huge design flaw:
MOST OF YOUR ACTIONS ARE BOUND TO TWO KEYS.

This is a critical foil, and it leads to a lot of less fluid, more sticky" movement when it comes to dashing from cover to cover and hiding in shadows. Whenever you want to move fast
date: you have to hold down your sprint key. This also makes it so you automatically move over obstacles in the way
recommended: which means you can hurdle over obstacles and _COMPLETELY_ blow your cover.\n\nThis being said

reviewText: Splinter Cell: Blacklist is by far one of the most, if not the most, advanced games of 2013. The time of its release teetered on the brink of the next-gen console wars and easily pushed the boundaries of consoles and computers alike.\n\nThe action packed game play, interesting terrain settings, in-depth story and realistic detail will keep drawing gamers back over and again until the game is completed. Even then, they will be longing to finish the secondary objectives and play some good ol' Mercs VS. Spies. Even if you're not a stealth fan or did not enjoy previous Splinter Cell games, this one is definitely worth at least a rental due to its diversity in play styles. This is one game that has earned it's worth for every penny of the $59.99 price tag.

reviewText: Splinter Cell, a game that has been around for the past 14 years or so. It is one of those games you either love or hate. So if you are into the stealth and infiltration type of games (like Metal Gear Solid) or a militarised American James Bond, then this is definitely a game for you. We continue the story of Sam Fisher from his kick-♥♥♥ new base of operations and his wide arsenal of gadgets and upgrades. You do what Sam Fisher does best, kill bad guys and leave without a trace (most of the time) . However, I would not recommend this game for people who do not like lone wolf style games. This game is for tactical and patient players.\n7/10

reviewText: This is one of my all time favorite games. I bought it on the PS3, which was complete crap with graphics and load times. I never finished it, and my PS3 needs  a new (something expensive im sure) so I bought the deluxe edition again for $40. It is so much better on PC I am glad I have spent $100 on this game total now, Worth every penny, the gameplay is vicious and uncanny. The checkpoint system in this is brilliant, it adds perfect tension to every moment, and really makes you slow down and think. Since the first 3D stealth game on PS1, Tenchu stealth assassins, I have loved this genre. As it stands this is the pinncle of stealth espionage, and a timless gaming experience.

reviewText:
Tom Clancy’s Splinter Cell Blacklist is a perfect game, simply because it has no cons.

- great graphics
- very good story
- perfect game-play
- very good, supportive music and sound effects
- freedom to choose your personal game style, sneaky or aggressive
- extremely realistic actors and settings, guards, team-members, nothing feels artificial
- very good level design
- rpg elements, play to collect money and upgrade your gear and weapons
- co-op
- multi-player

I can't mention anything negative. This game is perfect.

reviewText:
Boy this game was chore to finish.

This is the first Clancy game I've played, and I expected a semi realistic stealth shooter, which allowed you choose a playstyle and go with it. I had read about how the playstyles were categorised as ghost, panther and assault.

I soon found out that the ghost playstyle is often either absolutely forced, or basically the only viable option. I hate playing ghost.

Moreover this game doesn't have quicksaves, and sometimes the checkpoints are imo way too far in between, so sometimes I had to put the game away simply because I had enough of playing the first 80% of a checkpoint for the 10th time.

Some side missions don't have checkpoints at all!

The AI is simply ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and your opponents have infinite gadgets (e.g. drones and grenades).

The damage model is also incredibly unrealistic. A bullet into the unprotected face of someone wearing a bowl helmet just makes a *PLING* sound and the helmet comes flying off. You can also put 3-4 bullets into the leg of someone with no apparent leg armor, and he just runs away. Oh and the heavies can step on a proximity mine without getting handicapped. Etc. etc...

The presentation is excellent on all accounts though. Well, the textures were a little lowres if I had to mention something.

If you love playing ghost style you'll probably like this game (although there is actually some forced FPS action in it too, not that I'm complaining).

Huge disappointment for me though: 55%

reviewText:
This isn't a bad game, per se, but it is terribly disappointing to me.  Conviction, its predecessor, was absolutely amazing and I therefore had very high hopes for Blacklist.  Where Conviction had a complete single-player campaign along with a variety of co-op missions that could be played solo, Blacklist has a whole bunch of co-op stuff mixed into the solo campaign;  I despise being unable to complete missions, unlock gear, etc in the solo campaign without doing online stuff.  The levels inside the campaign also feature a lot of co-op only stuff - doors, passages, and more that can't be done in a solo game.  Worse still, some of the unlocks require playing an iPhone/Android game and synching it with your Uplay account.  Honestly, doesn't UBI already have enough of my information without resorting to installing spyware on my phone?

In terms of actual gameplay, the game again suffers compared with its predecessor.  Nearly every enemy on every map in every difficulty is wearing a magic helmet that can somehow prevent all damage from a supersonic 7.62.  Seriously, you pop them in the head and they just turn around to see how shot them.  It absolutely ruins the mark & execute mechanic (armored targets don't die to the execution), and takes a huge amount of fun out of the game for me.  It simply should not be safer to enter melee combat with an enemy than to cap his head with a firearm.  I suspect the developers were trying to appease the crowd that whined about Conviction being too easy and ended up producing something that appeals to neither camp.

I'll possibly continue playing long enough to finish the game, especially if I find a co-op partner, but I'm really disappointed in the game and the direction of the franchise in general.

reviewText: I really enjoyed the mix between chaos theory like stealth, mixed with a little of convictions multi-kill mechanics. Also I think that they borrowed a little from the assassin's creed series by making it possible to scale all sorts of buildings. I was however disappointed with the use of drones/RC cars. They felt like a really  easy way to scout, and kill, your enemies. However where this game truly shines is its multiplayer. The classic version of spy vs mercenary returns, but this time with a few changes. You can completely customize your spy/merc for the situation at hand. Say you want to use a heavy weapon like a LMG, or a AK47, or if you want your own flying drone of death you can do that. But you leave yourself open. It reminds me much of the chaos theory's spy VS mercenary mode but with a newer more balanced action side added. Overall I would highly reccomend this game to anyone, especially  those who loved the original splinter cell series.

date:

To simplify that:
Launch game through Steam > Opens .bat file > Opens Uplay > Launches game.

reviewText:
Splinter Cell is good again.

This chapter bring back the pure stealth mode of the original games.

You can choose your style combining
- ghost (dont be detected and dont kill/arm anyone)
- Panther (dont be detected, and silent kill)
- Assault (classic shooter)

In the campaign there is at least one mission for each style, and you can customize the weapons and gear according to your preferences.

The campaign is solid, and is a good/classical spy/terrorist story.

Secondary missions are a little weak, and i expecialy dont like the idea of the almost necessity of co-op (some missions are co-op only) but if you have a friend to play with it should be ok for you.

As 2014 co-op matchmaking is useless

reviewText:
Something was changed in Splinter Cell: Blacklist, and what's left is a frustrating shade of what it once was. I'll get my first niggle out of the way first: no Quicksave function. Die, get detected, anything that compromises the mission and you're back to the beginning in most cases. I can't overstate the sheer frustration this causes for me. I like perfect, stealthy run throughs - I derive my enjoyment from seeing how a situation went wrong and going back to a 'just prior' save to try a different tactic. I don't want to be bumped right back to the beginning, to hear the same conversations, to trudge through the same hallways just to get to where I was. It's limiting and non-sensical to ditch a quicksave function in a stealth game.

Next up, the controls. No longer can you control the speed at which Sam moves with the mousewheel. Keyboard controls (although admittedly they can be mapped), do not feel intuitive. Sam feels clunky, a little on rails. The contextual actions he performs are jarring, sometimes unwelcome; mean to open that door instead of head into cover? It's 50/50 what will happen. I wanted to leapfrog a railing by a door, and instead booted it open in front of a small army all curious as to who this suicidal maniac was. It feels clumsy, and in a Splinter Cell game clumsy is something that will deal break everything.

So what about combat? Admittedly, I'm a stealth nut, I avoid it. But even I get bummed out when, after not being seen across the map in perfect shadow, the body I drag back to the same (seemingly hidden) location is located as if it had flashing neon lights on it. In fact, I *do* have flashing neon lights on me and I wasn't spotted in the same location....but the body was. It's that kind of lazy gameplay that kills this for me.

I love Splinter Cell. Adore it even. But something has been removed here and what's left doesn't feel like a Splinter Cell game. It doesn't have the same polish, the same sleekness or the same atmosphere.....hell, it doesn't have the same soul. I can see what Ubisoft have tried to do, and for the life of me I can't work out why it hasn't worked, but it hasn't. I can't figure out how this game got good reviews from fans of the genre, so the possibility exists that this is just my problem and not the game. But somehow I trust my gut and this game simply has not gripped me yet. I hope it does.

reviewText: Fantastic level design, polished stealth and fun gadgets make for a great experience. The only weak point to the game in my honest opinion is the storyline which could have been way better.\nThe game also has a series of coop missions which happen to be rather lengthy, require a lot of coordination and skill. You can choose between 3 different playstyles depending on what suits you best.\nMultiplayer packs a good bit of fun with its returning gamemode from Chaos Theory: Spies Vs Mercs in which spies playing in 3rd person have to hack terminals in order to win while 1st person mercs loaded with heavy gear have to prevent them from doing so.

reviewText:
Game : Splinter Cell Blacklist

Score : 7/10

Summary :

Overal Splintercell Blacklist brings back the old feeling Chaos Theory used to have, It's a game where the developers acctualy did their best to bring back that good old feeling of trying to stealth past enemies without being deteced, something that Double Agent lacked in my oppinion. The singleplayer is a nice storyline with a nice extra added feature to upgrade your plane, upgrading this said plane will give you advantages on the battlefield, from better radar to better goggles.

Considering i have played every Splinter cell series ever released on PC i think i know what i'm talking about by saying this is probably the best Splinter Cell they have released since Chaos Theory.

When it comes to Multiplayer they worked hard to try and get that old feeling back that Chaos Theory used to have, unfortunately i still feels a bit chunky sometimes however i have over 100+ hours in on Multiplayer, i have to say tho, i played it without a proper team, if you have friends that want to play it aswell i can easily imagine you hit the 200+ hours.

The Coop is pretty good aswell, although i suggest playing that with a friend aswell on LAN or Teamspeak, it makes the experience so much better!

All in all this game surpasses Double Agent and Conviction by far, they really got the old Splinter Cell feeling back and i for one can not wait until they start working/releasing the next one!

Good things about Splinter cell Blacklist

- A nice new feature to upgrade your plane to make things a bit easyer in Campaign Mode
- They smoothened out the upgrading/buying of new gear
- Good gameplay, after 5/10 minutes of playing i got the feeling back and it felt like i never left
- Versus/Multiplayer is a HUGE step forward and getting close to what Chaos Theory used to be
- No significant gamebreaking bugs

Bad

- The launch was a bit bad with Multiplayer not really working although all issues are resolved for me
- At the start of Versus you feel overwhelmed by not knowing all the controls
- I understand some things change, but i don't like the new voice of Sam Fisher :'( nor that he looks younger!
- I hope they release some patches with new maps somethimes ( NOT DLC the game on itself is expensive enough )

All in all Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Blacklist is a nice addition to the Splinter Cell franshise, if you liked Chaos Theory i suggest you buy this one as well.

-Please note this review is written on the base of my oppinion.

reviewText:
Good potential, spoiled by simplistic controls (as its just a console port). So many times hitting Q to enter cover would make him jump over the cover (which should be triggered by space), even when not sprinting.  Sprinting would often result in unintentionally jumping over things or climbing if you ran just a little to close to a wall or obstacle, totally spoilt the immersion of the game.

Storyline missions where very easy (but quite fun overall), 4E missions where much harder and some where very frustrating (mostly cos of control issues).

About half way through playing I had a power cut during play, resulted in Uplay losing all my progress, took me right back to the start, thankfully I was able to use windows restore to get back to the previous days save, but still had to redo a couple missions.

Overall I'd give it a 4 out of 10 and would not recomend it.

reviewText:
The game play, story and graphics are well done.  The concept is pretty cool, co-op game play fighting terrorists.  There is one large flaw with this game and that is the choppy graphics, audio malfunctions and long list of bugs.  I have a state of the art machine but had to downgrade DirectX 11 to 9 just to get the game to work.  Based on research on forums as well as some bench testing, we found the game was not really programed properly for Directx11,... seriously?  If it wasn't for the total screw up on the developer side this would be a perfect game.  I hope they patch thier mistakes otherwise, you might have trouble running this game with out some bugs.

My machine:

Windows 7
16 Gigs of RAM
i7 Processor
2 gig high end Asus GPU 256

Every game I've ever thrown at it, no problem with everything set on high,.. except this game?  Test your software before you sell it please.

reviewText:
I would not buy, I got it on sale and I still feel cheated. I gave Ubisoft another chance since I was feeling like playing a good Splinter Cell game and my friends had said good things about this game but now I am really wishing that Steam had a 12 hour return policy or something.

I played this game for 4 hours or so right after installing it and granted that is not alot of time, but after having to replay the the first mission 3 times before I found out that the game ONLY saves if you have Uplay in Online mode and even then ONLY of you have cloud sync enabled, and after playing through the campaign for a few of the main missions, the first stage of all the side missions and giving the MP a go, I was dissappointed by the fact it is not really a stealth game.

It is just another third person shooter commando game with cover based stealth elements added to appease fans of the series, yet Ubisoft fails to understand why we want those elements in the game at all. The Paladin base plane is a cool, if clumsily implemented, addition and I was hoping I would be able to go around interacting with the crew but business-woman-Rebecca, black-Sean and Bug Eyes don't serve any purpose other than to be menus that you have to click through in order to upgrade the plane or buy equipment. The one opportunity that I found for character development was a phone that you can call your daughter on after each mission and that results in awkwardly short conversations about what is going on usually followed by a keep your chin up kiddo" remark before Sam hangs up the phone.

If you are expecting something similar at all to the first 3 games (the good ones imo and I would go buy them again right now if they weren't still charging 7 dollars for 12 year old technology) you are going to be dissappointed. This one forces you

reviewText:
Rather than stripping out quality stealth content for the sake of including action sequences or big set pieces, this game simply puts the icing on top of the cake, as it should be. There is a lot of game to be had here. A satisfyingly lengthy campaign, a breadth of side missions that encourage different styles of play, and rather robust multiplayer options, both competitive in the form of the beloved Spies vs. Mercs and cooperative versions of every side mission. The campaign itself and the story it tells is something between a summer blockbuster and an engaging espionage thriller. And this dichotomy overall strains the story and spreads it rather thin. At times, there are even attempts at commentary on the state of the United States role in international conflict and the moral justification of our trial-less imprisonment of those in Guantanamo Bay. But this is juxtaposed right next to cringe inducing Hollywood hacking and a rather tired and cliche cast of characters. Charlie is the embodiment of all the stereotypical hacker tropes, messy clothes, awkward jokes, and all. Briggs is the up-and-comer eager to prove himself, torn between his former career in the CIA and his new, rather above—the-law position in Sam’s Crew. Grimm is a ball-busting, hard-nosed provider of intel who shares a rather strange amoutn of sexual tension with Sam considering she spent the last game lying, betraying, and shooting him. She’s also been made to look much less homely than before. But I guess that’s the creative license afforded by the rather confusing gulf between sequel and reboot which this game occupies.

Sam himself is what really makes this game feel like a reboot. There’s acknowledgement of past events of earlier games, and his daughter Sarah continues to grow, but Sam looks and sounds much younger than before. The closest comparison I can think of is when they replace James Bond. The history is there, the cast is there, some of the same players are there, but the tone and the central character is dramatically different. But I assure you I am not comparing this new Sam to Daniel Craig’s invigorating take on 007. Fischer is frankly a rather shallow character this time around. Full of youth and vigor and almost none of the cynicism or dry humor of his previous incarnations. I can understand why this is game where Michael Ironsides finally gave up on the series. Whereas he once described Fischer’s character as “a tool that had been used one too many times,” this interpretation of Fischer is a tool that is very much in working order and gung-ho ready to go do whatever is necessary for the Stars and Stripes. There is occasional friction between him and the crew around him, and even some with the higher ups in the government, but Sam’s attitude and “been there, done that” sort of look on life from earlier entries is altogether gone. And it’s certainly missed.

But playing action games for quality storytelling and compelling characterization is like watching wrestling for storytelling and characterization. You’ll occasionally be thrown a bone, but you’re missing the point. Splinter Cell is at it’s best between the cutscenes and that stays true here. And, largely, this is a very old-school feeling stealth game. while there is still the mark and execute “press Y to kill everyone” feature introduced in Conviction, it seemed much harder to reliably use in my Realistic difficulty playthrough. Many enemies wear helmets and a single shot to the head will do little more than ♥♥♥♥ them off and make your presence known. So hand-to-hand takedowns or Sam’s plethora of gadgets are generally better options than gunfire. And that’s if you choose to engage them at all.

For the first time outside of a Hitman game that I can recall, the game actively rewards the player for leaving enemies alone altogether. For every checkpoint you reach, you’ll be rewarded with points for every enemy you left entirely undisturbed. And it really motivates stealthy players to do their best to get by undetected and unnoticed. I found myself feeling guilty if I couldn’t find a  way to ghost through a section. This active rewarding of a ghostly play style is a lesson and a tactic that absolutely needs to be adopted by more stealth games (I’m looking at you, Thief 2014.)

But whether you choose to avoid, attack from the shadows, or altogether mow down those that oppose you, the game does a good job of  giving you feedback on your performance. Everything you do in a level feeds into one of three gameplay categories: Ghost, Panther, and Assault. At the end of every level you’ll be given a cash total for your performance in all three categories. And if you max out a certain category, you’ll be given even greater rewards for it. So while realistically speaking you’ll have a mixture of all three at the end of every mission, you’ll want to try and really focus on one playstyle in order to maximize your monetary gains. And those gains are used to upgrade your guns, your stealth suit, or your various support functions your crew offers from the plane.

This game really just gets it right where it matters. There are indeed a few minor annoyances I had which could be a major thorn in the side of other players, though. There is a whole section where you play as Briggs, the other operative on the plane, that plays out as a first person shooter. You can still ghost your way through, but the game really encourages you in this section to play it like Call of Duty. It really stuck out to me. There are also a few other sections where the non-combat routes are decidedly less emphasized than the direct approach.

reviewText:
Ubisoft is at it again, and after three years of development, it appears that Splinter Cell has embraced the true stealth genre once more. 2010's 'Conviction,' after three years of launch delays, was Ubisoft Montreal's answer to wanting to appeal to a wider audience, so Sam Fisher was sent in without a light meter nor the ability to perform knockouts, whistle or hide bodies.  Instead it was an action-heavy guns a-blazin' approach, with just enough stealth elements as an attempt to hold on to its core followers.  'Blacklist' has made up for that minor failure and then some, offering up some of the best gameplay, AI and combat mechanics the franchise has seen to date.  Further, the storyline is genuinely engaging and the voice acting is top shelf material, though sadly the voice acting services of the legendary Michael Ironside is missing for the first time in the franchise, strangely replaced by the capable but much younger Eric Johnson.

Sam Fisher, as usual, plies his counter-terrorist trade, this time against The Engineers, sending him around the globe.  Sam's base of operations is an airborne military jetliner, from which the player can upgrade his gear, accept side missions from the Echelon 4 team, or pursue the main storyline.  Between all the options, there is plenty of of gameplay to be had from a single player standpoint, with additional multiplayer co-op and merc vs. spy possibilities.

Though a bit linear in scope and lacking in memorable villianous character, 'Blacklist' is a welcome return to the Splinter Cell I've known and loved for over a decade.  If you are new to the franchise, pay the older titles a visit; the original 'Splinter Cell' still holds up very well.  I look forward to 'Splinter Cell 7,' slated for a 2015 release.  Or 2016.  Or 2017.

reviewText:
This isn't a bad game, per se, but it is terribly disappointing to me.  Conviction, its predecessor, was absolutely amazing and I therefore had very high hopes for Blacklist.  Where Conviction had a complete single-player campaign along with a variety of co-op missions that could be played solo, Blacklist has a whole bunch of co-op stuff mixed into the solo campaign;  I despise being unable to complete missions, unlock gear, etc in the solo campaign without doing online stuff.  The levels inside the campaign also feature a lot of co-op only stuff - doors, passages, and more that can't be done in a solo game.  Worse still, some of the unlocks require playing an iPhone/Android game and synching it with your Uplay account.  Honestly, doesn't UBI already have enough of my information without resorting to installing spyware on my phone?

In terms of actual gameplay, the game again suffers compared with its predecessor.  Nearly every enemy on every map in every difficulty is wearing a magic helmet that can somehow prevent all damage from a supersonic 7.62.  Seriously, you pop them in the head and they just turn around to see how shot them.  It absolutely ruins the mark & execute mechanic (armored targets don't die to the execution), and takes a huge amount of fun out of the game for me.  It simply should not be safer to enter melee combat with an enemy than to cap his head with a firearm.  I suspect the developers were trying to appease the crowd that whined about Conviction being too easy and ended up producing something that appeals to neither camp.

I'll possibly continue playing long enough to finish the game, especially if I find a co-op partner, but I'm really disappointed in the game and the direction of the franchise in general.

reviewText:
I would not buy, I got it on sale and I still feel cheated. I gave Ubisoft another chance since I was feeling like playing a good Splinter Cell game and my friends had said good things about this game but now I am really wishing that Steam had a 12 hour return policy or something.

I played this game for 4 hours or so right after installing it and granted that is not alot of time, but after having to replay the the first mission 3 times before I found out that the game ONLY saves if you have Uplay in Online mode and even then ONLY of you have cloud sync enabled, and after playing through the campaign for a few of the main missions, the first stage of all the side missions and giving the MP a go, I was dissappointed by the fact it is not really a stealth game.

It is just another third person shooter commando game with cover based stealth elements added to appease fans of the series, yet Ubisoft fails to understand why we want those elements in the game at all. The Paladin base plane is a cool, if clumsily implemented, addition and I was hoping I would be able to go around interacting with the crew but business-woman-Rebecca, black-Sean and Bug Eyes don't serve any purpose other than to be menus that you have to click through in order to upgrade the plane or buy equipment. The one opportunity that I found for character development was a phone that you can call your daughter on after each mission and that results in awkwardly short conversations about what is going on usually followed by a keep your chin up kiddo" remark before Sam hangs up the phone.

If you are expecting something similar at all to the first 3 games (the good ones imo and I would go buy them again right now if they weren't still charging 7 dollars for 12 year old technology) you are going to be dissappointed. This one forces you
date: at regular intervals to go on shooting rampages
recommended: there are entire side missions focused around having shootouts in the streets (although you can stealth your way through those too
hoursPlayed: but that always consists of looping around behind them and using cover based neck chops)

reviewText: Thomas Clancy's Rainbow Cell Recon Splinter Squad Ghost Assault 4 was a very enjoyable game. The 64 byte graphics and Ge-force physics along with the Nvidia Shield game engine puts this 2nd person shooter game way ahead of current standards. And can amazingly be play accross all platforms including Windows 93 (and Windows Phone),  Mac OS X 12, ios8.8, Android Jelly Kat Pie, and of course the very popular PalmOS. This game is truely remarkable with next generation consoles even lets you input your commands with Commander Mode similar to Command Prompt on Cortana. All of this integration leads to a seamless gameplay that makes great use of your Facebook Inc.'s Ocular Rift Beta VR headset. The game characters are brought to life by great voice actors such as Steve Ballmer, Snoop Dogg, and Siri. Overall a great page-turner that keeps you excited until the end, when it finishes. Recomend New York Times Best Seller 8/8.

reviewText: Cool gameplay. Cool music. Cool skin-tight latex body suits that demonstrate the effectiveness of P90X.  However, the lack of Michael Ironside's voice and performance prevents Blacklist from reaching maxmium coolness. A weathered man, a father, a war vet, I imagine Sam Fisher is pushing 55, yet in this rendtion of the Splinter Cell series, he is voiced by a pubescent child who is prone to lashing out at his inner party. It's as if they're making some lackadaisical attempt to turn Sam Fisher into a young and hip action icon that is possessed by teen angst, opposed to the sardonically dark humour that we've grown accustomed to over the years. I don't mind if they're trying to reinvent the protagonist of Splinter Cell in order to appeal to a younger generation, but if that's the case, put Sam Fisher to rest and don't sully his image more than you already have. Introduce a new Splinter Cell--this reverse aging thing is just too weird for me.\n\nAlso, Fisher, arguably one of the most skillful agents of espionage of all time, lacks the ability to take cover in a standing position, which I found odd.

reviewText: I really enjoyed the mix between chaos theory like stealth, mixed with a little of convictions multi-kill mechanics. Also I think that they borrowed a little from the assassin's creed series by making it possible to scale all sorts of buildings. I was however disappointed with the use of drones/RC cars. They felt like a really  easy way to scout, and kill, your enemies. However where this game truly shines is its multiplayer. The classic version of spy vs mercenary returns, but this time with a few changes. You can completely customize your spy/merc for the situation at hand. Say you want to use a heavy weapon like a LMG, or a AK47, or if you want your own flying drone of death you can do that. But you leave yourself open. It reminds me much of the chaos theory's spy VS mercenary mode but with a newer more balanced action side added. Overall I would highly reccomend this game to anyone, especially  those who loved the original splinter cell series.

date:

Launch game through Steam > Opens .bat file > Opens Uplay > Launches game.

reviewText:
Splinter Cell is good again.

This chapter bring back the pure stealth mode of the original games.

You can choose your style combining
- ghost (dont be detected and dont kill/arm anyone)
- Panther (dont be detected, and silent kill)
- Assault (classic shooter)

In the campaign there is at least one mission for each style, and you can customize the weapons and gear according to your preferences.

The campaign is solid, and is a good/classical spy/terrorist story.

Secondary missions are a little weak, and i expecialy dont like the idea of the almost necessity of co-op (some missions are co-op only) but if you have a friend to play with it should be ok for you.

As 2014 co-op matchmaking is useless

reviewText:
I am a hardcore fan of the original trilogy of Splinter Cell games - Splinter Cell, Pandora Tomorrow, and Chaos Theory. After  Ubisoft deviated from the source material for a few years, I'm happy to say Blacklist feels the most like the originals.
The game drops you straight into the fray and gameplay can be confusing until you know what you're doing.

Once you do have a hang of things though, it is incredibly fun. I play with my friends as often as I can because, while the campaign is a good time (if you pay attention (the plot is a bit complex)), the coop is the most fun. I've never really cared for the multiplayer, but it is fun.

It combines elements from the originals and Conviction and lets you choose how you want to play. Very worth the money.

reviewText:
Splinter Cell took a left turn and wound up here with a new voice actor for Sam and a hybrid of gameplay from all of the past titles.

In mine and my brother-in-law's opinion it is our favorite Splinter Cell game. The amount of customization options adds a ridiculous amount of tactics to approach any situation the way you want.

Highly recommended for fans of Splinter Cell and of the tactical stealth third-person shooter.

9.5/10

reviewText:
In my opinion, this is one of THE BEST splinter cell games out there, if not actually taking the crown. What I didn't really like about the others (cept for conviction), was the restrictions, I mean, what IF I wanted to be a gung ho kind of spy? You know, like that orc assasin in oblivion xD
All the other splinter cell games force you to be stealthy (nothing wrong with that, it's the game genre after all), but blacklist allows you to choose what you want (conviction too, a little bit). IMO in reality a spy would rather drop somebody before even giving that somebody a chance to even think about spotting him xD, so killing in a stealth game isn't really something out of character.

The thing is you aren't FORCED to play any particular way in blacklist (like chaos theory). To be honest, blacklist, if played full stealth (no knockouts) is EVEN MORE stealth based than chaos theory (standing in shadows 1m away from somebody and they not noticing you isn't really stealth).
When you can get by an army of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in broad daylight on perfectionist and not even be spotted once, I think that says a whole lot more about stealth than chaos theory where you just stick (mostly) to shadows... Don't get me wrong, I freaking love chaos theory xD

As I said, blacklist doesn't force you to be stealthy, if you just wanna see Fisher in badass action, let him kill everybody, I mean, I sometimes like to go around sneaking on people and then all of a sudden SHOTGUN TO THE FACE!!! xD

Blacklist is also harder for pure stealth, I mean, I did 100% in chaos theory on hardest difficulty without saving and loading, couldn't do it in blacklist though... (well tbh the train bug can be excused xD).

The pistol thingy in chaos theory and double agent (forgot it's name lol) made you OP in artificially illuminated areas, IMO. No such thing in blacklist.

Overall if you're REALLY unbiased while criticising, you'll get that the stealth in this one FAR outclasses any other splinter cell game, if you're going for stealth, that is ;)

Graphics whise, I really can't tell, I'm not a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, I usually run most of my games on the lowest to get as much FPS out of them as I can, even if I can run them at max xD

Sounds are amazing, but I REALLY MISS IRONSIDE!!! If I had the money, I'd pay im a few million $$$ to dub Fisher in this game xD

reviewText:
Yes it does have uPLay, but it's also a great game! I bought it during the steam sale because I had a blast playing this on my old xbox 360 and I remember putting hours into the multiplayer section of the game (I only stopped because I didn't wanted to pay for a live subscription anymore), now I can play it online for free everyday! (I recomend the clasic spies vs mercs mode, it's a blast!).

I played all SC games, and I have to say that this one does justice to the franchise (I know it's hard to get used to the new voice of Sam Fisher). Everyone can play the way they want to. You want to turn this steatlh game into a action TPS? No problem, put on better armor, crank up the guns and shoot away. Wanna play it in a more clasic SC style, being like a ghost? Oooh you should definitely try the perfectionist difficulty, it will require a lot of skill, but it's worth it.

Get this game now! I didn't had any problems with uPLay, so there is no reason not to get it! Cheers!

reviewText:
Awesome game for an awesome franchise.

I'm not the type of 100% stealth guy, just like first 2 thief games, but I enjoy some stealth tactics, mixed with some action. (Obviously this is not COD, BF or Quake)

Blacklist is an improvement over past Splinter Cell: Conviction (don't forget that Conviction is really good)

What can I say about Blacklist?

a) You can play it, just like you want (Avoid all enemies, kill all or some quietly or full action)
b) Awesome graphics
c) Different characters to play (Even some missions have FPS perspective)
d) Cooperative
e) Long campaign
f) Maps are in different locations
g) Great voice acting

reviewText:
Ubisoft are brilliant at running beloved franchises into the ground and they did exactly that with Splinter Cell. Everything after Chaos Theory is best forgotten, preferably using large quantities of alcohol.

Yes, Blacklist still has Conviction’s shooty-shooty bang-bang gameplay, but it’s fun shooty-shooty bang-bang gameplay and it works nicely alongside the newly returned sneaky-sneaky knife-knife gameplay.

Throw in Spies vs Mercs and a brilliant co-op mode and this game almost deserves the Splinter Cell name. Almost.

reviewText:
Something was changed in Splinter Cell: Blacklist, and what's left is a frustrating shade of what it once was. I'll get my first niggle out of the way first: no Quicksave function. Die, get detected, anything that compromises the mission and you're back to the beginning in most cases. I can't overstate the sheer frustration this causes for me. I like perfect, stealthy run throughs - I derive my enjoyment from seeing how a situation went wrong and going back to a 'just prior' save to try a different tactic. I don't want to be bumped right back to the beginning, to hear the same conversations, to trudge through the same hallways just to get to where I was. It's limiting and non-sensical to ditch a quicksave function in a stealth game.

Next up, the controls. No longer can you control the speed at which Sam moves with the mousewheel. Keyboard controls (although admittedly they can be mapped), do not feel intuitive. Sam feels clunky, a little on rails. The contextual actions he performs are jarring, sometimes unwelcome; mean to open that door instead of head into cover? It's 50/50 what will happen. I wanted to leapfrog a railing by a door, and instead booted it open in front of a small army all curious as to who this suicidal maniac was. It feels clumsy, and in a Splinter Cell game clumsy is something that will deal break everything.

So what about combat? Admittedly, I'm a stealth nut, I avoid it. But even I get bummed out when, after not being seen across the map in perfect shadow, the body I drag back to the same (seemingly hidden) location is located as if it had flashing neon lights on it. In fact, I *do* have flashing neon lights on me and I wasn't spotted in the same location....but the body was. It's that kind of lazy gameplay that kills this for me.

I love Splinter Cell. Adore it even. But something has been removed here and what's left doesn't feel like a Splinter Cell game. It doesn't have the same polish, the same sleekness or the same atmosphere.....hell, it doesn't have the same soul. I can see what Ubisoft have tried to do, and for the life of me I can't work out why it hasn't worked, but it hasn't. I can't figure out how this game got good reviews from fans of the genre, so the possibility exists that this is just my problem and not the game. But somehow I trust my gut and this game simply has not gripped me yet. I hope it does.

reviewText:
Good potential, spoiled by simplistic controls (as its just a console port). So many times hitting Q to enter cover would make him jump over the cover (which should be triggered by space), even when not sprinting.  Sprinting would often result in unintentionally jumping over things or climbing if you ran just a little to close to a wall or obstacle, totally spoilt the immersion of the game.

Storyline missions where very easy (but quite fun overall), 4E missions where much harder and some where very frustrating (mostly cos of control issues).

About half way through playing I had a power cut during play, resulted in Uplay losing all my progress, took me right back to the start, thankfully I was able to use windows restore to get back to the previous days save, but still had to redo a couple missions.

Overall I'd give it a 4 out of 10 and would not recomend it.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game. While my time played may be low here, I played it by other means and have beat it many times over. The Uplay version was broken for me, and that was the version I had before I decided to buy it again on Steam where the multiplayer and online functionality actually worked and it didn't crash on me at all. (I have no idea why Uplay wouldn't let me play multiplayer, or even connect, the game would also crash every 30 minutes on the dot, and Ubisoft's support didn't help in any way). Regardless of all the trouble I went through with it, I still recommend it to anyone who loves stealth games.

The story while kind of unoriginal and bland, still held up, and was done quite well. Some characters make their return from previous Splinter Cell games as well.

The game is visually stunning, and looks really good when it is cranked all the way up to Ultra settings. It is also optimized quite well, as I can play the game at a decent framerate on an old HD 7850.

The sound and voice acting are quite good as well. While I wish they kept the old voice actor from the previous Splinter Cells, the new one actually did quite well and grew on me in the end.

The gameplay is a lot like any other Splinter Cell except for in this one, they have 3 different kinds of playstyles that they reward you for. They are Assault, Panther, and Ghost. Assault being gun's blazing kill everyone, and you basically play the game as a 3rd person shooter. While playing it this way isn't exactly my cup of tea, the game does allow you to if you choose to. Ghost is basically the exact opposite of the spectrum, and I actually recommend playing it this way. Trying to figure out guard's routes, and all the different secret nooks and crannies you can hide in or around without being seen is one of most fun ways to play. You are also awarded with more points if you go completely undetected, and  can sneak your way past guards without touching any of them. Lastly, Panther is a combination of both Assault and Ghost where you use stealth, but also kill whoever crosses your path. They did decide to leave in the Mark and Execute from Conviction which is a little annoying, and I think makes parts of the game entirely too easy, but just I chose not to use it throughout my playthrough.

The level design is quite good, and even though I wish it was a little more open, there are still multiple ways to complete missions. Most areas have different paths you can take to get around undetected.

Overall, I put Blacklist in a close second to Chaos Theory. Everything is done really well, and this game was my favorite game of 2013 when it came out. If you are a fan of stealth games, I think it is a must have. I recommend cranking the difficulty all the way up to Perfectionist, and trying to go through completely unseen. It can be frustratingly difficult this way, but it's not impossible, and in my opinion the most satisfying way to play the game. Definitely recommend to anyone that is a fan of the genre.

reviewText:
Rather than stripping out quality stealth content for the sake of including action sequences or big set pieces, this game simply puts the icing on top of the cake, as it should be. There is a lot of game to be had here. A satisfyingly lengthy campaign, a breadth of side missions that encourage different styles of play, and rather robust multiplayer options, both competitive in the form of the beloved Spies vs. Mercs and cooperative versions of every side mission. The campaign itself and the story it tells is something between a summer blockbuster and an engaging espionage thriller. And this dichotomy overall strains the story and spreads it rather thin. At times, there are even attempts at commentary on the state of the United States role in international conflict and the moral justification of our trial-less imprisonment of those in Guantanamo Bay. But this is juxtaposed right next to cringe inducing Hollywood hacking and a rather tired and cliche cast of characters. Charlie is the embodiment of all the stereotypical hacker tropes, messy clothes, awkward jokes, and all. Briggs is the up-and-comer eager to prove himself, torn between his former career in the CIA and his new, rather above—the-law position in Sam’s Crew. Grimm is a ball-busting, hard-nosed provider of intel who shares a rather strange amoutn of sexual tension with Sam considering she spent the last game lying, betraying, and shooting him. She’s also been made to look much less homely than before. But I guess that’s the creative license afforded by the rather confusing gulf between sequel and reboot which this game occupies.

Sam himself is what really makes this game feel like a reboot. There’s acknowledgement of past events of earlier games, and his daughter Sarah continues to grow, but Sam looks and sounds much younger than before. The closest comparison I can think of is when they replace James Bond. The history is there, the cast is there, some of the same players are there, but the tone and the central character is dramatically different. But I assure you I am not comparing this new Sam to Daniel Craig’s invigorating take on 007. Fischer is frankly a rather shallow character this time around. Full of youth and vigor and almost none of the cynicism or dry humor of his previous incarnations. I can understand why this is game where Michael Ironsides finally gave up on the series. Whereas he once described Fischer’s character as “a tool that had been used one too many times,” this interpretation of Fischer is a tool that is very much in working order and gung-ho ready to go do whatever is necessary for the Stars and Stripes. There is occasional friction between him and the crew around him, and even some with the higher ups in the government, but Sam’s attitude and “been there, done that” sort of look on life from earlier entries is altogether gone. And it’s certainly missed.

But playing action games for quality storytelling and compelling characterization is like watching wrestling for storytelling and characterization. You’ll occasionally be thrown a bone, but you’re missing the point. Splinter Cell is at it’s best between the cutscenes and that stays true here. And, largely, this is a very old-school feeling stealth game. while there is still the mark and execute “press Y to kill everyone” feature introduced in Conviction, it seemed much harder to reliably use in my Realistic difficulty playthrough. Many enemies wear helmets and a single shot to the head will do little more than ♥♥♥♥ them off and make your presence known. So hand-to-hand takedowns or Sam’s plethora of gadgets are generally better options than gunfire. And that’s if you choose to engage them at all.

For the first time outside of a Hitman game that I can recall, the game actively rewards the player for leaving enemies alone altogether. For every checkpoint you reach, you’ll be rewarded with points for every enemy you left entirely undisturbed. And it really motivates stealthy players to do their best to get by undetected and unnoticed. I found myself feeling guilty if I couldn’t find a  way to ghost through a section. This active rewarding of a ghostly play style is a lesson and a tactic that absolutely needs to be adopted by more stealth games (I’m looking at you, Thief 2014.)

But whether you choose to avoid, attack from the shadows, or altogether mow down those that oppose you, the game does a good job of  giving you feedback on your performance. Everything you do in a level feeds into one of three gameplay categories: Ghost, Panther, and Assault. At the end of every level you’ll be given a cash total for your performance in all three categories. And if you max out a certain category, you’ll be given even greater rewards for it. So while realistically speaking you’ll have a mixture of all three at the end of every mission, you’ll want to try and really focus on one playstyle in order to maximize your monetary gains. And those gains are used to upgrade your guns, your stealth suit, or your various support functions your crew offers from the plane.

This game really just gets it right where it matters. There are indeed a few minor annoyances I had which could be a major thorn in the side of other players, though. There is a whole section where you play as Briggs, the other operative on the plane, that plays out as a first person shooter. You can still ghost your way through, but the game really encourages you in this section to play it like Call of Duty. It really stuck out to me. There are also a few other sections where the non-combat routes are decidedly less emphasized than the direct approach.
